chunks.original_text: 书符都毕，北向叩齿三十六通，微祝曰： 九天有命，普告万灵，三代相推，五气交并，玉帝显驾，匡辔霄庭，施布正法，收魔束精，剪戮元祆，万道齐平，道流后学，帝君记名，招真洞幽，气交无形，变景炼道，升上三清，得迅飞舆，上造玉庭。 毕，随位置符，真仙立降，身无祸殃，学无此道，鲜不丧身，可谓妙法，不学自仙也。 金真玉光行道服气存思三真法二十六 上元宫泥丸中脑是也，其神赤子字三元先，一名仲玄生帝卿。 中元宫绛房中心是也，其神真人字子南丹，一名中光坚。 下元丹田宫脐下三寸是也，其神婴儿字元阳昌，一名谷下玄。 些三一之神矣，欲拘制魂魄时，皆先阴呼其名，存三神皆玉色金光，有婴儿之貌，中上二元皆衣赤，下元衣黄，头如婴儿始生之状，行道服气时亦存名字。 七圣玄纪仙禁七伤法二十七 凡学士玄纪有名，身合仙相，则应自然合真，而有： 第一之伤，带真行伪，淫色丧神，魂液泄漏，精光枯乾，气散魄零，骨空形振，神泣穷府，上闻天关，真仙远游，则与九尘结因，土府同符。 岂复得仙。 第二之伤，外形在道，皮好念真，而心抱阴贼，凶恶内臻，愿人否败，嫉能妬贤，口美心逆，面欢内嗔，形论得失，妄造罪原，毁谤同学，攻伐师根，三官所记，标为恶门，仙真高逝，邪魔攻身，走作形影，飞散体神，故令枉横，极其恶原，考满形灰，灭己九泉，徒有玄名，岂保自然。 第三之伤，饮酒洞醉，损气丧灵，五府攻溃，万神振惊，魂魄飞散，内外朽零，本室空索，赤子悲鸣，真仙高逝，邪魔入形。 如此之学，徒损精诚，虽有玄纪，空失玉名，神升上宫，身灰幽冥，恍惚求延，年焉久停。 第四之伤，行不弘物，责人宗仰，心忿口形，骂詈无常，瞋喜失节，意性乖恒，气激神散，内真飞扬，魄离魂游，九孔尘埃，五府奔丧，皆由性之不纯，行之不祥，真仙高逝，外痾入形。 如此之学，将欲何蒙，虽有玄图，不免斯殃，望仙日悠，地里日长。 第五之伤，或玄图表见，得受宝经，或运遇灵师，启授神文，或不依科盟，形泄天真，未经九年，投刺名山，使青宫有录，金阙结篇，便传於人，流散世间，轻真泄宝，考结己身，徒有玄名，反累七玄，仙道高逝，身死幽泉，长充鬼责，万劫不原。 第六之伤，身履殗秽，形影不香，内无清虚，外无兰芳，清灵失仙，神不居房，气扰精混，灵元失光，五神飞散，赤子骞扬，邪魔来攻，内外交丧，如此之学，望成反伤，真仙高逝，空景独行，沦於混浊，仙乎可蒙。 第七之伤，啖食一切含生之肉，杀害足口之美，臭气充於脏腑，伐生形於非己，真气扰於灵门，游神骇於赤子，魂魄游於宫宅，浊滞缠於口齿，仙真登高於玉清，己身沈顿於地里，徒有玄名於帝简，亦不免於必死。 高圣帝君曰：为学道之本，当以七伤为急，既得瞻眄洞门，披睹玉篇，不犯七伤之禁，将坐待灵降，白日升晨。 如外勤在学，内不遣於七伤者，将望仙而反败，期生而反亡，希吉而反凶，期飞而反沈，灵仙逝於高清，五神散於八荒，赤子号泣於中宅，游魂悲鸣於玄空，故仙相有成败，上学有七伤，笃尚之士，孰清其真。 灵书紫文仙相十败法二十八 第一败勿好淫，淫则魂液外漏，精光枯竭，神焦魄散，骨薄髓秽，魂号灵府，上闻天阁，三宫权争，胎英悲错。

Once the talismans are fully inscribed, face north and strike the teeth thirty-six times, then softly intone the prayer:

*"By decree of the Nine Heavens,
A summons is proclaimed to the myriad spirits.
Three eras succeed one another,
Five qi intermingle and merge.
The Jade Emperor reveals His chariot,
Guiding the reins in the celestial court,
Disseminating the true Dharma,
Subduing demons and restraining spirits,
Severing and slaying primordial evil.
May the ten thousand Dao be leveled as one.
Disciples of the Dao and later learners,
Your names are recorded by the Imperial Lord.
Summon the true and penetrate the hidden,
Where qi converges without form.
Transform the luminous and refine the Dao,
Ascend to the Three Clarities,
Attain swift-flying chariots,
And ascend to the Jade Court."*

Upon completion, place the talismans according to their positions. True immortals will descend at once, and the practitioner will be free from misfortune and calamity. Those who do not study this Dao seldom escape bodily ruin. Truly, this is a wondrous method—without study, one attains immortality by nature.

**Golden True Jade Radiance Dao-Practicing Qi-Absorbing Visualization of the Three Perfected Ones Method (26)**

The Upper Prime Palace resides in the *niwan* (mud-pill palace) within the brain. Its spirit is the Red Child, named Three Primes First, also called Zhongxuan Shengdi Qing.

The Middle Prime Palace resides in the crimson chamber of the heart. Its spirit is the Perfected One, named Zinan Dan, also called Zhongguang Jian.

The Lower Prime Palace resides in the cinnabar field three inches below the navel. Its spirit is the Infant, named Yuanyang Chang, also called Guxia Xuan.

These are the Three Ones’ spirits. When seeking to restrain the hun and po souls, first silently invoke their names. Visualize the three spirits as jade-like with golden radiance, appearing in the form of infants. The Middle and Upper Primes both wear red, while the Lower Prime wears yellow. Their heads resemble those of newborn infants. During Dao-practicing and qi-absorbing, also visualize their names.

**Seven Sacred Mysteries: The Prohibitions Against the Seven Harms (27)**

For all scholars of the Mystic Register who possess the countenance of immortality, they should naturally unite with the true. Yet there are seven harms:

**The First Harm:** Donning the true while practicing falsehood, indulging in lust and dissipating spirit. The hun’s essence leaks, the radiance of essence withers, qi scatters, and the po disperses. Bones hollow, the form trembles, the spirit weeps in the exhausted palace. This is heard at the Celestial Gate, and true immortals journey far away. One thus binds karmic ties with the Nine Dusts, becoming akin to the Earthly Bureau. How can one still attain immortality?

**The Second Harm:** Outwardly appearing devoted to the Dao while inwardly harboring malice. Wickedness festers within, wishing others ill and failure. Envy of the capable and jealousy of the worthy. Sweet words with treacherous hearts, smiling faces with inner wrath. Judging others’ gains and losses, recklessly creating the roots of sin. Slandering fellow disciples, attacking the foundation of one’s teacher. Recorded by the Three Officials as an evil gate, immortals ascend on high while demonic forces assail the body. The form becomes a wandering shadow, the spirit scatters, and one suffers unjust calamities. At the extreme of evil’s origin, the body is reduced to ashes, and one is extinguished in the Nine Springs. Though bearing a mystic name, how can one preserve the natural?

**The Third Harm:** Drinking to profound intoxication, harming qi and losing spirit. The five palaces collapse, the myriad spirits are startled, the hun and po scatter, and the inner and outer decay. The original chamber stands empty, the Red Child wails in sorrow, true immortals ascend on high, and demonic forces enter the form. Such learning only wastes essence and sincerity. Though one bears the Mystic Register, the jade name is lost in vain. The spirit ascends to the upper palace, while the body turns to ashes in the dark underworld. Seeking to prolong life in confusion, how can one endure?

**The Fourth Harm:** Conduct that does not benefit others, demanding reverence from others. Heart filled with resentment, words of abuse without restraint. Anger and joy without moderation, temperament erratic and unsteady. Qi agitates and spirit scatters, the inner true flees, the po departs, and the hun wanders. The nine orifices gather dust, the five palaces flee in disarray. All stems from an impure nature and inauspicious conduct. True immortals ascend on high, while external afflictions enter the form. With such learning, what benefit can one hope for? Though bearing the Mystic Chart, one cannot escape this calamity. The hope for immortality grows distant, while the path to the underworld lengthens.

**The Fifth Harm:** Possessing the Mystic Chart’s outward signs, having received treasured scriptures, or encountering a spiritually attuned master who imparts sacred texts. Yet failing to adhere to the precepts and covenants, one leaks celestial truths. Before nine years have passed, one petitions famous mountains, causing the Azure Palace to record the name and the Golden Portal to compile the account. Then, one transmits these to others, dispersing them among the world. Treating the true lightly and leaking the treasured, one incurs karmic retribution upon oneself. Though bearing a mystic name, one instead burdens the Seven Mysteries. The immortal Dao ascends on high, while the body perishes in the dark springs, forever bearing ghostly debts, never to be absolved for ten thousand kalpas.

**The Sixth Harm:** The body treading in filth and impurity, the form and shadow lacking fragrance. Inwardly devoid of purity and emptiness, outwardly lacking orchid-like fragrance. The pure and numinous lose their immortality, the spirit does not dwell in its chamber. Qi is disturbed, essence is muddled, the numinous origin loses its radiance. The five spirits scatter, the Red Child flees, demonic forces attack, and the inner and outer perish together. With such learning, hoping to succeed only brings harm. True immortals ascend on high, while the solitary luminous scene wanders alone, sinking into turbidity. How can one attain immortality?

**The Seventh Harm:** Consuming the flesh of all living beings, slaughtering and harming the beauty of those with limbs and mouths. Foul qi fills the viscera, cutting short the lives of others for one’s own form. True qi is disturbed at the numinous gate, the wandering spirit startles the Red Child. The hun and po wander through the palace chambers, turbidity and stagnation cling to the mouth and teeth. Immortals ascend to the Jade Clarity on high, while one’s own body sinks into the underworld. Though bearing a mystic name in the Imperial Register, one cannot escape certain death.

The Most High Sage Lord said: The foundation of studying the Dao lies in urgently avoiding the Seven Harms. Once one has gazed upon the gates of the Mystic Caverns and perused the jade scriptures, without transgressing the prohibitions of the Seven Harms, one may sit and await the descent of the numinous, ascending to the dawn in broad daylight. If one outwardly strives in learning yet inwardly does not dispel the Seven Harms, one will seek immortality but instead meet defeat, hope for life but instead perish, aspire to fortune but instead encounter misfortune, and long to ascend but instead sink. The numinous immortals depart to the High Clarity, the five spirits scatter to the eight wastes, the Red Child wails in the central chamber, and the wandering hun cries out in the Mystic Void. Thus, the countenance of immortality has its successes and failures, and advanced learning has its Seven Harms. For those who earnestly uphold the Dao, who can purify their truth?

**Purple Text of the Numinous Book: The Ten Failures of the Immortal Countenance (28)**

**The First Failure:** Do not indulge in lust. Lust causes the hun’s essence to leak externally, the radiance of essence to wither, the spirit to scorch, and the po to scatter. Bones thin, marrow becomes foul, the hun wails in the numinous palace. This is heard at the Celestial Pavilion, the Three Palaces contend for authority, and the Embryonic Flower laments in error.

**The Second Failure:** Do not engage in treacherous malice or cruelty. Cruelty causes the Yellow Court to descend into chaos, the Three Corpses to delight in slaughter, the hun-spirit to spy on deceit, and the po-ghost to invade the chamber. The eyes’ light perishes, and the mouth emits harmful qi. **This is the second failure of the immortal countenance.**

The Red Child takes flight and cries out, while the throat and brain are scorched by fire. **This is the third failure of the immortal countenance.**

**The Fifth Failure:** Do not consume the flesh of any living being. Doing so severs the primordial form at its origin, destroys the root and foundation, and causes the Embryonic Spirit to wail in lament, the Crimson Lord to cry out in longing. The Three Hun grow bitter with poison, the po wanders among graves and mounds. If you violate the heavenly prohibitions, you will suffer harm and failure.

**The Twenty-Ninth Method: The Yellow Plain and High Clarity Robes of the High Clarity Scripture**

The High Clarity ritual robe is made of purple and blue silk, with purple on the outside and blue on the inside. The robe’s width is four feet and nine inches, corresponding to the number of the four seasons. Its length is five feet and five inches, aligning with the qi of heaven and earth. The outer and inner layers follow a single pattern: the outer layer has twenty-four strips, and the inner layer has fifteen strips, corresponding to the thirty-nine positions of the Perfected Emperors. Thus, wearing this robe signifies donning the attire of the Thearch and Sovereign. Without this robe, one must not recklessly handle the precious scriptures. This ritual robe is bestowed upon twelve Jade Lads. It must not be lent to others, nor may it be defiled by impurity or treated with disrespect.

For women, the purple gauze robe uses two zhang and four chi of fabric. The sleeves should be made long enough to suit the body. The robe should have sixteen strips on the sleeves and twenty-three strips on the body, totaling thirty-nine strips. Additionally, a blue gauze skirt is made using forty-five chi of fabric, divided into eight panels. Each panel is four feet and nine inches long, with the remaining fabric used for the waistband. The eight panels are further divided into thirty-two strips, forming the Flying Blue Skirt. Without this ritual robe, one must not recite the High Clarity precious scriptures. This robe is bestowed upon twelve Jade Maidens. It must not be lent to others, nor may it be defiled by impurity or treated with disrespect.

chunks.original_text: 上帝出游，日吉时良，玉华覆盖，太一扶将，左翼白元，右辅无英，八帝九真，陵梵履昌，导我送我，与我同光，履行五岳，群仙奉迎，出入河海，万道开张，役御六丁，足蹑五行，三天有命，荡除万凶，豁落扫秽，流金灭殃，正法清通，严如威霜，华精奕奕，龙舆昂昂，流青翠羽，飞锦罗裳，所向所之，靡不吉昌，万真来朝，齐升玉京。 毕，引气三十六咽止。 行此千日，得五岳真仙降云车羽盖，飞行太空。 凡道士入山良月吉日禁忌之法 道士欲入山，以三月七日吉。 又法，春不东山及西山，夏不南山北山，秋不西山东山，冬不北山南山。 入山良日，保、义、专日吉，制、伐日并凶。 甲子、丙寅、丁卯、己巳、辛未、壬申、癸酉、乙亥、庚辰、辛丑、庚戌、戊午，此是义日，吉。 丁丑、丙戌、甲午、庚子、壬寅、癸卯、乙巳、丁未、戊申、己酉、辛亥、丙辰，此是保日，吉。 戊辰、己丑、戊戌、丙午、壬子、甲寅、乙卯、丁巳、己未、庚申、辛酉、癸亥，此是专日，吉。 乙丑、甲戌、壬午、戊子、癸巳、甲辰、庚寅、辛卯、乙未、丙申、丁酉、己亥，此是制日，凶。 庚午、丙子、戊寅、己卯、辛巳、癸未、甲申、乙酉、丁亥、壬辰、癸丑、壬戌，此是伐日，凶。 道士若卒遇凶恶不祥，当打天钟三十六过，叩左齿也。 道士若经山辟邪威神大祝，当槌天磬三十六过，叩右齿也。 若存思念道，致真招灵，当鸣天鼓三十六过，叩上下齿也。 凡道士独宿山林，而多为山精恶鬼所犯试者，当叩齿二七通，闭气祝曰： 吾昨被帝召，摄领真元，令我封掌北岳，摧割酆山，万灵受事，俱会帝前，七神启别，三元司真，若有小祆，即时枭残，山精泽尉，速来奉迎，神师口命，上闻三清，一如大洞之法，不得稽停。 祝毕，又叩齿二七通。 此为帝君补神祝伐山精百鬼之法，诸山神地祇，房祠主正之神，闻此之祝，皆执鞭奉迎，神兵侍卫，若与万人同宿矣。 凡受三品上道，或未得上登三清受号仙主者，多为天魔所试，万灵所干也，宜咏拂魔之祝，上动上天之灵音，下召三界之威神，束万精於天锺，斩祆魔於洞章。 行此之法，常当北向，先存项生圆象如日，左有朱凤，右有玄龙，紫霞覆盖，光明身形，仙童玉女，执五色之节，从三界万神，前啸九凤，后吹八鸾，白虬启道，太极参轩。 毕叩左齿三十六通，次叩右齿二十四通，次叩上下齿十二通，而祝曰： 罗天毒兽，备巨四门，吞沈割誓，山丑万群，张喉玃天，猛马高奔，毒龙奋爪，金头横吞，威兵巨万，受符校仙，六天不拘，合凶成群，祆魔鼓洋，秽气纷纷，谣歌空洞，乱音鄣云，小鬼贾刑，当人生门，神王所告，无幽不闻，上摄六气，下检河源，五岳四渎，善恶速分，万万千千，来对我前，五帝校录，有功者原，凶魔千真，束形帝君，敢不从命，所诛无蠲，屠肝刳腹，斩首灭根，北镬渍汤，南陵火焚，金真录气，流铃捕魂，祆爽无遗，极尽形源，身佩天书，道行正文，涤荡九气，清明三元，玄虚举真，上合自然，莫有干试，改动上闻。 毕，引气十二咽止。 右智慧拂魔之祝。 凡是学士游行名山，在百鬼之间独宿振怖，及婴抱疾病，群鬼守门，诵之一过，将似镬汤之消冰，炎火之洋金也，魂神澄正，气安体强，目非禀命之应，终求死不可得矣。

**The August Thearch’s Procession**

When the August Thearch sets forth on his journey, the day is auspicious, the hour propitious. Jade radiance spreads its canopy; the Great One lends his support. On the left, the White Prime attends; on the right, the Peerless Flourishing assists. The Eight Thearchs and Nine Perfected, ascending Brahmā’s realm, treading in prosperity, guide me and escort me, sharing their brilliance with me. As I traverse the Five Marchmounts, the host of immortals comes forth to welcome me. Entering and exiting rivers and seas, ten thousand paths open wide. I command the Six Dings and tread the Five Phases. The Three Heavens issue their decree, sweeping away the myriad evils. With a mighty sweep, defilement is purged; flowing metal annihilates calamity. The Orthodox Dharma flows pure and clear, stern as the frost’s authority. Resplendent essence shines forth; the dragon chariot rears high. Verdant plumes and azure feathers flutter; flying brocade and silk robes trail. Wherever I go, wherever I turn, all is felicitous and prosperous. The myriad Perfected come to pay homage, ascending together to the Jade Capital.

When finished, draw in qi thirty-six times and cease.

Practicing this for a thousand days, one will have the True Immortals of the Five Marchmounts descend in cloud chariots with feathered canopies, soaring through the Great Void.

**Auspicious Days and Taboos for Daoists Entering Mountains**

When a Daoist wishes to enter a mountain, the seventh day of the third month is auspicious.

Another method: In spring, do not enter eastern or western mountains; in summer, do not enter southern or northern mountains; in autumn, do not enter western or eastern mountains; in winter, do not enter northern or southern mountains.

For entering mountains, *Bao*, *Yi*, and *Zhuan* days are auspicious; *Zhi* and *Fa* days are inauspicious.

*Yi* days (auspicious): Jiazi, Bingyin, Dingmao, Jisi, Xinwei, Renshen, Guiyou, Yihai, Gengchen, Xinchou, Gengxu, Wuwu.

*Bao* days (auspicious): Dingchou, Bingxu, Jiawu, Gengzi, Renyin, Guimao, Yisi, Dingwei, Wushen, Jiyou, Xinhai, Bingchen.

*Zhuan* days (auspicious): Wuchen, Jichou, Wuxu, Bingwu, Renzi, Jiayin, Yimao, Dingsi, Jiwei, Gengshen, Xinyou, Guihai.

*Zhi* days (inauspicious): Yichou, Jiaxu, Renwu, Wuzhi, Guisi, Jiachen, Gengyin, Xinmao, Yiwei, Bingshen, Dingyou, Jihai.

*Fa* days (inauspicious): Gengwu, Bingzi, Wuyin, Jimao, Xinsi, Guiwei, Jiashen, Yiyou, Dinghai, Renchen, Guichou, Renxu.

If a Daoist suddenly encounters inauspicious or malevolent omens, strike the Heavenly Bell thirty-six times and knock the left teeth.

When passing through mountains and reciting the mighty incantation to ward off evil spirits, strike the Heavenly Chime thirty-six times and knock the right teeth.

When meditating on the Dao to summon the True and attract the numinous, sound the Heavenly Drum thirty-six times and knock the upper and lower teeth together.

**Incantation to Subdue Mountain Spirits and Malevolent Ghosts**

If a Daoist, lodging alone in mountain forests, is often harassed or tested by mountain spirits and malevolent ghosts, knock the teeth fourteen times, hold the breath, and recite:

*"Yesterday, I was summoned by the Thearch to assume command of the True Prime, ordering me to seal and govern the Northern Marchmount and demolish Mount Feng. The myriad spirits receive their duties and assemble before the Thearch. The Seven Spirits initiate their departure; the Three Origins govern the True. If any minor demons dare act, they shall be instantly annihilated. Mountain spirits and marsh wardens, hasten to receive my command. The divine master’s oral decree is heard above by the Three Clarities. All proceeds according to the Great Cavern’s method; no delay is permitted."*

After reciting, knock the teeth fourteen times again.

This is the incantation of the Thearch-Lord to supplement the spirits and subdue mountain spirits and the hundred ghosts. When the mountain gods, earth deities, and the spirits presiding over shrines and temples hear this incantation, they all wield whips to welcome, and divine soldiers stand guard. It is as if ten thousand people were lodging together.

**Incantation to Dispel Demons**

Those who have received the Three Superior Daoist Teachings but have not yet ascended to the Three Clarities to receive their immortal titles and ranks are often tested by heavenly demons and harassed by the myriad spirits. They should chant the incantation to dispel demons, which stirs the numinous sounds of the Upper Heavens above and summons the mighty spirits of the Three Realms below. It binds the myriad spirits to the Heavenly Bell and beheads demonic forces with the Cavern Scripture.

To perform this method, always face north. First visualize a round image like the sun rising from the nape of the neck, with a vermilion phoenix on the left and a dark dragon on the right. Purple radiance spreads its canopy, illuminating the body’s form. Immortal youths and jade maidens hold five-colored standards, accompanied by the myriad spirits of the Three Realms. Before them, nine phoenixes cry; behind them, eight simurghs sing. White dragons clear the path; the Great Ultimate attends the chariot.

First knock the left teeth thirty-six times, then the right teeth twenty-four times, then the upper and lower teeth together twelve times, and recite:

*"O ravenous beasts of the Nether Heavens, guarding the four great gates! Swallowing and drowning, severing oaths, the mountain’s ugliness gathers in myriad hordes. They bare their throats to the heavens; fierce horses gallop high. Poisonous dragons brandish their claws; golden heads devour horizontally. Mighty soldiers number in the tens of thousands, receiving talismans to examine immortals. The Six Heavens are unrestrained, joining evil to form hordes. Demons drum and surge; defiled qi swirls in profusion. Empty cavern songs and chaotic sounds obstruct the clouds. Petty ghosts trade punishments, targeting the gate of human life. The divine kings proclaim: there is no seclusion they do not hear. Above, they seize the Six Qi; below, they inspect the river sources. The Five Marchmounts and Four Watercourses swiftly distinguish good from evil. By the tens of thousands, by the thousands, they come before me. The Five Thearchs examine and record: those with merit are pardoned. A thousand demons and true spirits, their forms bound by the Thearch-Lord—dare they not obey the command? Those executed shall know no reprieve. Their livers shall be carved, their bellies ripped open, their heads severed, their roots extinguished. In the northern cauldron, they shall be steeped in boiling water; in the southern mound, they shall be burned by fire. The Golden Perfected records their qi; the Flowing Bell captures their souls. No trace of demonic corruption shall remain; their forms and origins shall be utterly exhausted. Bearing the Heavenly Scriptures on their bodies, their Dao and conduct follow the Orthodox Text. They cleanse and purify the Nine Qi, clarifying the Three Origins. The Mysterious Void uplifts the True, uniting above with the Natural. Let none dare harass or test me; any disturbance shall be reported above."*

When finished, draw in qi twelve times and cease.

This is the **Incantation of Wisdom to Dispel Demons**.

Whenever a scholar of the Dao travels through famous mountains, lodging alone amidst a hundred ghosts, trembling with fear, or when illness clings like an infant, and a host of ghosts guards the door—reciting this incantation once is like ice melting in a boiling cauldron or metal dissolving in scorching flames. The hun-soul and spirit become serene and upright; qi is calmed, the body strengthened. Even if one’s fate were not destined to end thus, in the end, death itself would be unattainable.
